dt: {bc}to roll oneself about in a lazy, relaxed, or ungainly manner

dt.t: allowed them to {wi}wallow{/wi} in their ignorance

et: Middle English {it}walwen{/it} "to turn oneself over and over, writhe about, roll oneself in a substance, indulge oneself unrestrainedly," going back to Old English {it}wealwian{/it} "to roll (of a round object), to roll from side to side (of a person or animal), roll in a substance," going back to Germanic {it}*walwōjan-,{/it} iterative derivative of a base {it}*walw-,{/it} also in Gothic {it}afwalwjan{/it} "to roll away (an object)," {it}atwalwjan{/it} "to roll up to," going back to Indo-European {it}*u̯ol-u̯-,{/it} ablaut derivative of a base {it}*u̯el-u̯-,{/it} whence Latin {it}volvō, volvere{/it} "to set in a circular course, cause to roll" (< {it}*u̯eluu̯ō{/it}), Greek {it}eilýō, eilýein{/it} "to wrap round, envelop," Armenian {it}gelum{/it} "to twist, squeeze"
The base {it}*u̯el-u̯-{/it} is taken to be an extension of {it}*u̯el-{/it} "roll"—see etymology and note at {et_link|welter:1|welter:1}.
shortdef: to roll oneself about in a lazy, relaxed, or ungainly manner
to devote oneself entirely; especially : to take unrestrained pleasure : delight
